subject: Fix DHCP failure of vm with sg which has no rule
messages:
[{'account_id': 29874, 'date': '2019-04-30 09:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-06 15:02:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I see both this and https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657179/ for the same bug, I think one can be abandoned as a duplicate.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-05-07 12:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Duplicated with: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657179/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-30 09:09:53.000000000', 'message': "Fix DHCP failure of vm with sg which has no rule

This patch is adding acl rule in 'ls_in_acl' table of logical flow
to allow dhcp traffic.Even a vm with sg has no rule can also get its
offered ip address.

Change-Id: I8112c305a8f7080e4385b712b7198a464d351836
Related-Bug: #1790900
"}]
commit_message:
Fix DHCP failure of vm with sg which has no rule

This patch is adding acl rule in 'ls_in_acl' table of logical flow
to allow dhcp traffic.Even a vm with sg has no rule can also get its
offered ip address.

Change-Id: I8112c305a8f7080e4385b712b7198a464d351836
Related-Bug: #1790900

commit_message:
bootstrap: install network-scripts if EL8

network-scripts is required by the network service which is enabled
in tasks/main.yml.
Also run this block of tasks on EL8 only, where it's actually needed.

Change-Id: I2e43de001938bcdec96875ede0ef52d4742dc01c
Closes-bug: 1827277
(cherry picked from commit 878a7727b9d019c0520edb88c020e4eb740271f9)

[{'created': '2019-05-03 22:35:50.000000000', 'message': 'Log when port resource is leaked during port delete

When a bound port deleted in the neutron nova got notified and the port
is detached from the server. However if the port had resource request
then the resulting allocation is leaked.

This patch makes sure nova at least logs and ERROR. Also this patch
asserts that the leaked allocation is reclaimed when the server is
deleted.

commit_message:
Log when port resource is leaked during port delete

When a bound port is deleted in neutron, nova gets a
network-vif-deleted notification and the port is
detached from the server. However if the port had resource request
then the resulting allocation is leaked.

This patch makes sure nova at least logs an ERROR. Also this patch
asserts that the leaked allocation is reclaimed when the server is
deleted.

Change-Id: I5d905aeb5b25f84d406dbf238d0d3a46f0f81161
Related-Bug: #1820588

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-15 17:03:15.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Use migration_status during volume migrating and retyping

When swapping volumes Nova has to identify if the switch itself is
realted to an underlying migration or retype of the volume by Cinder.
Nova would previously use the status of the volume to determine if the
volume was retyping or migrating.

However in the migration case where a volume is moved directly between
backends this status has never been set by Cinder and would result in
Nova never calling the os-migrate_volume_completion cinder API to
complete the migration.

This change ensures that migration_status is now used to ensure that
this API is called for both retypes and migrations.

Change-Id: I1bdf3431bda2da98380e0dcaa9f952e6768ca3af
Closes-bug: #1803961
'}, {'created': '2019-02-18 22:29:01.000000000', 'message': 'Use migration_status during volume migrating and retyping

When swapping volumes Nova has to identify if the swap itself is related
to an underlying migration or retype of the volume by Cinder.  Nova
would previously use the status of the volume to determine if the volume
was retyping or migrating.

However in the migration case where a volume is moved directly between
hosts the volume is never given a status  of migrating by Cinder leading
to Nova never calling the os-migrate_volume_completion cinder API to
complete the migration.

This change switches Nova to use the migration_status of the volume to
ensure that this API is called for both retypes and migrations.

Change-Id: I1bdf3431bda2da98380e0dcaa9f952e6768ca3af
Closes-bug: #1803961
'}, {'created': '2019-02-24 19:19:25.000000000', 'message': 'Use migration_status during volume retype and migration

When called to swap attached volumes Nova has to identify if the swap
itself relates to an underlying migration or retype of the volume by
Cinder. Nova would previously use the status of the volume being set to
migrating to determine if the volume was retyping or migrating.

However in the migration case where Cinder is moving the volume directly
between backends the status is never set to migrating, This would
previously lead to Nova never calling the os-migrate_volume_completion
cinder API to complete the migration as documented in bug #1803961.

This change corrects this by switching Nova to use the migration_status
of the volume to determine when a volume is being retyped or migrating.
In both cases the volume will have a migration_status of migrating when
Nova is called by Cinder to swap to the new volume. This will then
ensure that the os-migrate_volume_completion API is called correctly
once Nova has completed the swap.

Change-Id: I1bdf3431bda2da98380e0dcaa9f952e6768ca3af
Closes-bug: #1803961

commit_message:
Use migration_status during volume migrating and retyping

When swapping volumes Nova has to identify if the swap itself is related
to an underlying migration or retype of the volume by Cinder.  Nova
would previously use the status of the volume to determine if the volume
was retyping or migrating.

However in the migration case where a volume is moved directly between
hosts the volume is never given a status  of migrating by Cinder leading
to Nova never calling the os-migrate_volume_completion cinder API to
complete the migration.

This change switches Nova to use the migration_status of the volume to
ensure that this API is called for both retypes and migrations.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/639331/
Change-Id: I1bdf3431bda2da98380e0dcaa9f952e6768ca3af
Closes-bug: #1803961

commit_message:
Get the stack name if possible before running the validations group

If we run the group validations in the Undercloud and we
do not specify the stack name, this will fail if the
Overcloud stack is not called 'overcloud'.

In this case we try to fetch the stack name and we compare it
with the swift containers to match the deployment plan name
if there is a match, then we know the stack name.

Change-Id: Ib2e27b1b43f573385c089e57bd2290daac49d814
Closes-Bug: 1806684
Resolves: rhbz#1573120

Change-Id: I1251f33a2a93b0d99574dc94ca000b1f4eb9be99
'}, {'created': '2019-05-06 10:42:16.000000000', 'message': 'Fix incompatibility between stestr-2.3.1 and ostestr

Currently there is an incompatibility between stestr-2.3.1 and os-testr,
because of which tox jobs are failing in networking-ovn. This is because
ostestr passes --concurrency None to stestr and after [1] merged, stestr
is expecting only integer values. Till [2] is not released in the
updated stestr version, run stestr with --concurrency 0 so that parallel
jobs (number of jobs = number of CPUs) can run with stestr, thus fixing
the issue with tox and the gate failures resulting because of this
inconsistency.

[1]: https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/commit/c93bc81
[2]: https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/commit/ac8dac0

Related-Bug: #1827834
Change-Id: I1251f33a2a93b0d99574dc94ca000b1f4eb9be99

commit_message:
Set ostestr concurrency to 0 to fix networking-ovn gate

Currently due to an incompatibility between stestr-2.3.1 and os-testr,
gate jobs are failing in networking-ovn. This is because ostestr passes
--concurrency None to stestr and after [1] merged, stestr
is expecting only integer values. Till [2] is not released in the
updated stestr version, run stestr with --concurrency 0.
--concurrency 0 allows to run as many jobs as there are CPUs in the
system, allowing parallel execution in stestr.
This temporarily fixes the issue with tox and the gate failures
resulting because of this inconsistency. Once [2] is released, this
change can be reverted.

[1]: https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/commit/c93bc81
[2]: https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/commit/ac8dac0

Related-Bug: #1827834
Change-Id: I1251f33a2a93b0d99574dc94ca000b1f4eb9be99

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-23 12:41:06.000000000', 'message': 'Support defining the free space in the image

Currently diskimage-builder supports two ways to specify the image
size. One is defining a fixed image size using DIB_IMAGE_SIZE, the
other one is auto-detection while adding a security margin of 66% as
free space. This means when building larger images (e.g. >100GB) with
unknown size upfront we end up with much wasted space, IO and network
traffic when uploading the images to several cloud providers. This can
be optimized by adding a third way by defining DIB_IMAGE_EXTRA_SIZE to
specify the free space in GB. This makes it possible to easily build
images of varying sizes while still minimizing the overhead by keeping
the free space constant to e.g. 1GB.

Change-Id: I114c739d11d0cfe3b8d8abc6df5ff989edfb67f2

commit_message:
Support defining the free space in the image

Currently diskimage-builder supports two ways to specify the image
size. One is defining a fixed image size using DIB_IMAGE_SIZE, the
other one is auto-detection while adding a security margin of 60% as
free space. This means when building larger images (e.g. >100GB) with
unknown size upfront we end up with much wasted space, IO and network
traffic when uploading the images to several cloud providers. This can
be optimized by adding a third way by defining DIB_IMAGE_EXTRA_SIZE to
specify the free space in GB. This makes it possible to easily build
images of varying sizes while still minimizing the overhead by keeping
the free space constant to e.g. 1GB.

Change-Id: I114c739d11d0cfe3b8d8abc6df5ff989edfb67f2

I think I have to remove my opposition here, because I just can see a practical way to do this otherwise.  we can pass this size into the block-device tool, for sure ... but then what?  

I considered we could just eval() the size and allow arbitrary python in the image-size argument.  this would suck.

I considered that we could do a sort of "magic" image-size in the yaml, so if it starts with "bc" we could run it through that tool and get the result, passing along some environment variables to boot.  i started writing this and it just seemed ridiculous.

We could do something similar with a pass-through to $(( )) but it's about as bad as eval()

I really do not want to pull in some sort of maths parsing library, that seems ridiculous.

So while I don't see this as really the way we *want* to go, I can't come up with anything practical.

@Yolanda -- obviously very open to suggestions'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-29 07:07:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-29 07:09:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Another change came in (https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655127/2) which really needs to do a similar thing for the same reasons discussed here.  Rather than hold all this up, I've written up some more specific documentation on what's going on with these options (https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656255/1) and rebased this ontop of it.

I've added this option to that documentation, and added a release note."}, {'account_id': 16068, 'date': '2019-05-02 19:45:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-05-07 08:54:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-26 20:07:54.000000000', 'message': 'Allow specification of filesystem journal size

In many cases, the statically sized 64MB journal is far below the
e2fstools default calculation[0] which calls for a 64MB journal only
on filesystems smaller than 16GB. On bare metal in particular, the
correct default journal size will often be in the 512MB-1GB range.

Since we cannot know what the target system is, this should be a
tunable parameter that the user can set depending on the intended
image usage.

Add a DIB_JOURNAL_SIZE envvar and --mkfs-journal-size parameter
to the image creation so users can override the default journal
size.

Also adjust the default DIB journal to 128MB to more closely
reflect a typical image deployment once deployed and filled to
the size of the disk.

[0] https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/fs/ext2/e2fsprogs.git/tree/lib/ext2fs/mkjournal.c#n333

Change-Id: I65fa13a088eecdfe61636678578577ea2cfb3c0c

commit_message:
Allow specification of filesystem journal size

In many cases, the statically sized 64MB journal is far below the
e2fstools default calculation[0] which calls for a 64MB journal only
on filesystems smaller than 16GB. On bare metal in particular, the
correct default journal size will often be in the 512MB-1GB range.

Since we cannot know what the target system is, this should be a
tunable parameter that the user can set depending on the intended
image usage.

Add a DIB_JOURNAL_SIZE envvar and --mkfs-journal-size parameter
to the image creation so users can override the default journal
size.

[0] https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/fs/ext2/e2fsprogs.git/tree/lib/ext2fs/mkjournal.c#n333

Change-Id: I65fa13a088eecdfe61636678578577ea2cfb3c0c

commit_message:
Skip attaching FloatingIP if it is already attached

There are some flows in the cloud layer (reuse, but not found), which
try to attach a freshly allocated (and attached) FIP. There is at least
one cloud in the crowd, which explicitely forbids FIP attachment when it
is already attached, what results in SDK and Ansible failure with
auto_ip=True

The test test_add_ip_refresh_timeout is being removed, since normally we
should never end up this way (with reuse=False we wait for the FIP to be
assigned during creation and we leave _add_auto_ip on a short-cut)

Change-Id: If9a217981237d6f851ee470717da01fddd1b5ff1

commit_message:
Adding root_execution_id to the jinja executor function

This makes getting a root_execution_id possible without having to go
through filtering and querying the executions search.

Change-Id: Ia6c954e688589f69a7463f1b8e02244d029e8b7a

commit_message:
Added tripleo job template against new collect-logs role

In order to test new collect-logs, we are moving jobs step by
step in order to make sure it does not break any thing.

It adds following jobs:
 tripleo-standalone-scenarios-full
 tripleo-undercloud-jobs
 tripleo-multinode-container-full

It covers three different scenario for testing new collect-logs
role.

https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/999

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/654934/
Change-Id: Ie9603f2ae1937b3aed093081dacada461bf883cd
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add assertions to attached volume retype test

Previously only the volume type and timestamp data was checked when
retyping an attached volume. This change adds additional assertions to
ensure the volume state remains `in-use`, volume migration state is
`success` and the same `volume_id` remains attached to the instance
after the retype completes. This final check ensures that nova has
correctly called the os-migrate_volume_completion cinder API.

Related-bug: #1803961
Change-Id: I32f0611bdfd2ccede73e7ab774286f5315ff92c3

commit_message:
Document the various global filesystem options

These options have always been a bit of a mess since v2 when we added
all the block-device flexibility.  Add some explicit documentation to
try and help explain the relationship between these options and the
block-device config.

Change-Id: I49affcbef868d644f673b833bef8310cf25cfd0f

the placement query will not match with the numbering in the flavor
extra spec. But still each group has its own unique number.

Change-Id: I1e552d6dfef77d98638463ca2c309cc658e02445
'}, {'created': '2019-03-26 16:27:53.000000000', 'message': "Add flavor to requested_resources in RequestSpec

RequestGroups created from neutron ports are added to the
requested_resources already but the RequesSpec itself and
the Flavor stored in the Request spec also contains
requested resources or required traits both for the unnumbered
and possibily for multiple numbered groups.

This patch moves the translation of these requests from the
allocation candidate query generation codepath to the RequestSpec
create and update codepath. This way the RequestGroups are created
earlier so that extra finetuning can be done based on RequestGroup
objects instead of injecting flavor extra_spec keys.

On the other hand this also means that if some fields of the
RequestSpec object changes then the request groups needs to be
regenerated. For example the request filters are changing the
RequestSpec before the scheduling. So after those filters run the
RequestGroups needs to be regenerated. This is problematic becase
anyting that is added directly to the RequestGroups generated from
the RequestSpec before the request filters run will be lost as those
groups are re-generated based on the updated content of the RequestSpec.

Note: Detecting the changes of the RequestSpec fields is not easy. The
pythonic way would be to define a @property for each fields with getters
and setters and trigger the RequestGroup re-generation from the setter.
Unfortunately OVOs autogenerate properties that are overwrite the
properties added to an OVO manually (See bug 1821619).
Even if OVO would allow defining properties it would be impossible to
run the RequestGroup re-generation from the setter because such setter
can be called on an half initialized object. For example OVO's
__deepcopy__ first instantiate a new OVO object then copies its fields
one by one. Therefore it calls some setter while the OVO is not fully
initialized. This means it is the caller's responsibility to call the
RequestGroup re-generate method after some field is set on the
RequestGroup.

Note: This patch in its current form changes how the request groups
are numbered in the allocation candidate query. The numbering in
the placement query will not match with the numbering in the flavor
extra spec. But still each group will have the appropriate content and
has its own unique number.

Change-Id: I1e552d6dfef77d98638463ca2c309cc658e02445
"}]
commit_message:
Add flavor to requested_resources in RequestSpec

RequestGroups created from neutron ports are added to the
requested_resources already but the RequesSpec itself and
the Flavor stored in the Request spec also contains
requested resources or required traits both for the unnumbered
and possibily for multiple numbered groups.

This patch moves the translation of these requests from the
allocation candidate query generation codepath to the RequestSpec
create and update codepath. This way the RequestGroups are created
earlier so that extra finetuning can be done based on RequestGroup
objects instead of injecting flavor extra_spec keys.

On the other hand this also means that if some fields of the
RequestSpec object changes then the request groups needs to be
regenerated. For example the request filters are changing the
RequestSpec before the scheduling. So after those filters run the
RequestGroups needs to be regenerated. This is problematic becase
anyting that is added directly to the RequestGroups generated from
the RequestSpec before the request filters run will be lost as those
groups are re-generated based on the updated content of the RequestSpec.

Note: Detecting the changes of the RequestSpec fields is not easy. The
pythonic way would be to define a @property for each fields with getters
and setters and trigger the RequestGroup re-generation from the setter.
Unfortunately OVOs autogenerate properties that are overwrite the
properties added to an OVO manually (See bug 1821619).
Even if OVO would allow defining properties it would be impossible to
run the RequestGroup re-generation from the setter because such setter
can be called on an half initialized object. For example OVO's
__deepcopy__ first instantiate a new OVO object then copies its fields
one by one. Therefore it calls some setter while the OVO is not fully
initialized. This means it is the caller's responsibility to call the
RequestGroup re-generate method after some field is set on the
RequestGroup.

Note: This patch in its current form changes how the request groups
are numbered in the allocation candidate query. The numbering in
the placement query will not match with the numbering in the flavor
extra spec. But still each group will have the appropriate content and
has its own unique number.

Change-Id: I1e552d6dfef77d98638463ca2c309cc658e02445

commit_message:
Fix IPv6 in Active/Standby topology on CentOS

Avoid duplicated IPv6 VIP addresses on CentOS in Active/Standby mode,
Keepalived will set/unset the VIP address.

Story: 2005365
Task: 30340

Change-Id: I05b31ba628bafeefec36cc5c000dae1aefb63d67
(cherry picked from commit 951afb9a0a94413f8d452fa5516cf4dc412968a7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-06 21:06:36.000000000', 'message': 'Skip notification sample tests when running nova functional

The notification sample tests are many and at least some of
them contribute quite a bit of time so may as well not run
them when placement runs the nova functional tests.

In a recent run those tests took ~11.5 minutes to run in total,
with ~6.5 minutes being devoted to the actual tests.

Tuning this to perfection is probably a fools errand but
making tweaks when there are obviously useless (in this
context) time consumers, may as well kill them.

(Not listing a task here as the story has already merged
so the following syntax will operate similar to related-bug.)

Change-Id: I8f762cbf0ce2126609b7c24a8054785e252bdd03
Story: 2005562
'}]
commit_message:
Skip notification sample tests when running nova functional

The notification sample tests are many and at least some of
them contribute quite a bit of time so may as well not run
them when placement runs the nova functional tests.

In a recent run those tests took ~11.5 minutes to run in total,
with ~6.5 minutes being devoted to the actual tests.

Tuning this to perfection is probably a fools errand but
making tweaks when there are obviously useless (in this
context) time consumers, may as well kill them.

(Not listing a task here as the story has already merged
so the following syntax will operate similar to related-bug.)

Change-Id: I8f762cbf0ce2126609b7c24a8054785e252bdd03
Story: 2005562

commit_message:
Documentation enhancements

In order to cover the new metrics.yml configuration file structure,
the documentation as been reworked.

The usage of a standalone Cloudkitty deployement, in a non-OpenStack
context is also covered.

Collector-specific configuration and examples are also provided.

Change-Id: I8dcd25aac6dcb2ac70f867275647650283d2125f

Enhance utils.py to support local time zone

Add a bunch of wrapper functions in utils.py for implementing business
logic of local time zone support. Also UT is added.

Change-Id: Iee5415465733ae0206a1ce5949336f47c05b13bf
Implements: blueprint local-time-zone-support

commit_message:
Allow Cloudkitty to collect data sources from a timestamp

Also simplify the way that the timestamp is retrieved
and calculated by Cloudkitty classes.

Change-Id: Ibc518cebe3d70025d9c203c89699220abb77953d
Story: 2003928

commit_message:
Fixed wrap from taking negative values

Now for wrap input it will take only postive integers as an input and
if any negative numbers are give it will give output as "Wrap argument
should be a positive integer".

Change-Id: I8026b304d3d0646b85ef8557647408099efb1a48

commit_message:
Fix : To return Duplicate Error occured 500 Internal Error in dashboard.

* It should implement it so that you know what is already in use.
  so, Add to receive duplication exception 409.

Change-Id: Id61770905e6f7a7a5355d5290be95f15484ca790
Closes-bug: #1718098

Refactor boundary calculation logic

Refactor boundary calculation logic of current month so that ensure
calculated boundary is based on local time zone.

Depends-On: Iee5415465733ae0206a1ce5949336f47c05b13bf

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-01 22:36:04.000000000', 'message': 'Package db migration scripts in placement pypi dist

Having the db migration scripts within the openstack-placement pypi
distribution is desirable for deployment tools, such as
openstack-ansible. It provides a known good location for the script,
available with a pip install.

There are several ways to distribute files with a python package. The
method used here was chosen because it works both with tarballs and
wheels (the files are already in the tarball, as a result of the way pbr
works, but not in the wheel).

Here's what's done:

* The db migrate scripts are put in their own direcory,
  placement_db_tools, so that only they are packaged, not the other
  tools.
* To preserve how grenade interacts with these files as well as not
  disrupt the docs, symlinks from tools to placement_db_tools have been
  created.
* placement_db_tools is added to the list of packages included in the
  openstack-placement distro. This means that when 'pip install
  openstack-placement' happens, the python environment will then include
  placement and placement_db_tools directories.

The end result is that the true path to the script can be found with:

  pkg_resources.resource_filename('placement_db_tools', 'mysql-migrate-db.sh')

This has been noted in the to-stein.rst document.

A different package was chosen to not muddy the waters of what is
"actually placement".

Similarly, the 'data_files' functionality provided by pbr was not used,
because that requires the file be written to a location on the local
filesystem, relative to the install prefix. Dirtying the filesystem
outside the python lib with this sort of thing is inappropriate.

Change-Id: Ie326ce8a2a0692d20793bc18be606e034fa94a44
Story: 2005535
Task: 30671

commit_message:
Package db migration scripts in placement pypi dist

Having the db migration scripts within the openstack-placement pypi
distribution is desirable for deployment tools, such as
openstack-ansible. It provides a known good location for the script,
available with a pip install.

There are several ways to distribute files with a python package. The
method used here was chosen because it works both with tarballs and
wheels (the files are already in the tarball, as a result of the way pbr
works, but not in the wheel).

Here's what's done:

* The db migrate scripts are put in their own direcory,
  placement_db_tools, so that only they are packaged, not the other
  tools.
* To preserve how grenade interacts with these files as well as not
  disrupt the docs, symlinks from tools to placement_db_tools have been
  created.
* placement_db_tools is added to the list of packages included in the
  openstack-placement distro. This means that when 'pip install
  openstack-placement' happens, the python environment will then include
  placement and placement_db_tools directories.

The end result is that the true path to the script can be found with:

  pkg_resources.resource_filename('placement_db_tools', 'mysql-migrate-db.sh')

This has been noted in the to-stein.rst document.

A different package was chosen to not muddy the waters of what is
"actually placement".

Similarly, the 'data_files' functionality provided by pbr was not used,
because that requires the file be written to a location on the local
filesystem, relative to the install prefix. Dirtying the filesystem
outside the python lib with this sort of thing is inappropriate.

Change-Id: Ie326ce8a2a0692d20793bc18be606e034fa94a44
Story: 2005535
Task: 30671

commit_message:
Skip image validation if failed

This allows image validation to fail and continue lauching the
container. This is because image validation might depend on
external image registry (i.e. DockerHub) which is not always stable.

Change-Id: I3c65cdef17d8279233bfbb74a38c9db79b01a2de
Closes-Bug: #1827968

commit_message:
Support k8s installation

Add support for installing kubernetes cluster via devstack.
It uses kubeadm to bootstrap the k8s cluster.

Using NIC numbering in SRIOV parameters

This change is to use NIC numbering alias name instead of actual
NIC name for SRIOV numvfs and physical device mappings parameters.

Add option to allow a deployer to manually set master nodes

A deployer can now mark specific nodes as masters by adding hosts to
the "elastic-masters" group.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-13 19:11:01.000000000', 'message': 'Move the kibana index creation to the index playbook

The kibana index process was being run after kibana installation however
that creates an inconsistent experience as a user would expect these
indexes to be created during our general purpose index playbook. This
change moves the index creation tasks that were in the kibana playbook
to address the UX issue.

Change-Id: I76cab678c9c164455dc8bd03e6158655fc4d103e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-10-13 19:12:11.000000000', 'message': 'Move the kibana index creation to the index playbook

The kibana index process was being run after kibana installation however
that creates an inconsistent experience as a user would expect these
indexes to be created during our general purpose index playbook. This
change moves the index creation tasks that were in the kibana playbook
to address the UX issue.

Another UX issue is that users expect the default index to be filebeat
(formerly logstash) the default index is now being set to "filebeat-*"
which will ensure an expected experience.

Change-Id: I76cab678c9c164455dc8bd03e6158655fc4d103e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Move the kibana index creation to the index playbook

The kibana index process was being run after kibana installation however
that creates an inconsistent experience as a user would expect these
indexes to be created during our general purpose index playbook. This
change moves the index creation tasks that were in the kibana playbook
to address the UX issue.

Another UX issue is that users expect the default index to be filebeat
(formerly logstash) the default index is now being set to "filebeat-*"
which will ensure an expected experience.

Change-Id: I76cab678c9c164455dc8bd03e6158655fc4d103e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

The nspawn container create process does not create any package cache at
the completion of the create process which results in a broken cache. To
correc the issue an apt_force_update option has been added to ensure
nspawn containers always have an updated cache when the playbooks are

commit_message:
Add force update option for apt

The nspawn container create process does not create any package cache at
the completion of the create process which results in a broken cache. To
correc the issue an apt_force_update option has been added to ensure
nspawn containers always have an updated cache when the playbooks are
running the nspawn-container-create playbook.

Change-Id: I538abb34c9f7de0dfd2425e4023b54f77804f6ca
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-04 05:19:15.000000000', 'message': 'Move tasks and block them to better handle creates

The container create tasks were running all runs. this change blocks the
tasks and adds a conditional to the block which ensures that effort is
not wasted on a role rerun.

The container create process needs to gather the machine-id and set it
in the config to ensure that the journals are logged on the host and not
just running within the container, which can result in a full fs. This
change adds the machine-id slurp task so that the value can be used in
config which will ensure the mount is handled correctly.

Change-Id: I8e0ce74d988657a256059c9d81dca063139ffaee
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-07-04 05:31:30.000000000', 'message': 'Move tasks and block them to better handle creates

The container create tasks were running all runs. this change blocks the
tasks and adds a conditional to the block which ensures that effort is
not wasted on a role rerun.

The container create process needs to gather the machine-id and set it
in the config to ensure that the journals are logged on the host and not
just running within the container, which can result in a full fs. This
change adds the machine-id slurp task so that the value can be used in
config which will ensure the mount is handled correctly.

The environment variable used in a "read only" bind mount was removed
because it did far more harm than good, epecially if/when it's needed to
modity a specific environment within a container.

Change-Id: I8e0ce74d988657a256059c9d81dca063139ffaee
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-07-10 14:22:12.000000000', 'message': 'Move tasks and block them to better handle creates

The container create tasks were running all runs. this change blocks the
tasks and adds a conditional to the block which ensures that effort is
not wasted on a role rerun.

The container create process needs to gather the machine-id and set it
in the config to ensure that the journals are logged on the host and not
just running within the container, which can result in a full fs. This
change adds the machine-id slurp task so that the value can be used in
config which will ensure the mount is handled correctly.

The environment variable used in a "read only" bind mount was removed
because it did far more harm than good, epecially if/when it's needed to
modity a specific environment within a container.

Change-Id: I8e0ce74d988657a256059c9d81dca063139ffaee
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Move tasks and block them to better handle creates

The container create tasks were running all runs. this change blocks the
tasks and adds a conditional to the block which ensures that effort is
not wasted on a role rerun.

The container create process needs to gather the machine-id and set it
in the config to ensure that the journals are logged on the host and not
just running within the container, which can result in a full fs. This
change adds the machine-id slurp task so that the value can be used in
config which will ensure the mount is handled correctly.

The environment variable used in a "read only" bind mount was removed
because it did far more harm than good, epecially if/when it's needed to
modity a specific environment within a container.

Change-Id: I8e0ce74d988657a256059c9d81dca063139ffaee
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Convert self-signed SSL to use the openssl modules

The current process uses command tasks to generate self-signed
certificates. This removes our useage of command tasks in favor
of using the ansible modules. As part of the old key
distribution process we used to store the entire key in memory
for the duration of the runtime. While this process worked very
well, it has the potential to consume a lot of memory. The new
tasks will now syncronize the generated certificates using a pull
and push model instead of store the key in facts.

In order to use the new certificate modules the python-openssl
library has been added as a dependency.

Change-Id: Ie1e505e64ffb231c3475f88588105804d0022bdb
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Convert self-signed SSL to use the openssl modules

The current process uses command tasks to generate self-signed
certificates. This removes our useage of command tasks in favor
of using the ansible modules. This also removes some of the extra
tasks we had which are no longer required. As part of the old key
distribution process we used to store the entire key in memory
for the duration of the runtime. While this process worked very
well, it has the potential to consume a lot of memory. The new
tasks will now syncronize the generated certificates using a pull
and push model instead of store the key in facts.

In order to use the new certificate modules the python-openssl
library has been added as a dependency.

Change-Id: I039624d4a10aac3784fa8e4cb820066b6d6dd680
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

At the very least I think we need to get some tests implemented around this

I wonder if it might be possible to use the standard ansible vars ansible_become and ansible_become_user to implement this for both the container su and the physical host su as describe in https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1645732

ie.
[all]
physical1 ansible_become=yes
container1 physical_host=physical1 ansible_become=no
^ su to root on host, execute without su in container

[all]
physical1
container1 physical_host=physical1 ansible_become=yes
^ do not su on host, su within container

[all]
physical1 ansible_become=yes
container1 physical_host=physical1 ansible_become=yes
^ su on host, su inside the container before running module


I have not fully read thru the patch to understand which of these scenarios are supported here. Also not sure if it would be possible to use the standard ansible become vars on the container/physical host inventory items to determine sudo functionality.'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2018-03-30 15:17:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Allow remote user to "become" when managing containers

Presently the connection plugin assumes the remote user is root however
it's entirely possible that the executing user is not root and that the
user running the playbooks has to escalate privileges to manage container
infrastructures. This change allows the remote user to "become" another
user while also allowing the container execution user to be set to
something else entirely which ensures we're able to use all of the built
in functionality that Ansible provides to escalate privileges.

Several new debug statements have been added which provide more insight
on how the plugin is running when debug is enabled.

Change-Id: Ic2cecf9531613769c2cb4142cf7e99516a82c1ff
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-04 16:20:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add a playbook to set local facts on newton redeploy

The newton redeployment process, while fairly straight forward, cna have
issues due to transient problems or DB states. This change sets all of
the known local facts for a newton deployment within the new target
containers during the redeployment process. This will ensure that all
local facts are set prior to running the redeployment which will also
effectively finish the upgrade for the cloud.

Change-Id: I8f04bbda500459222e727c3de9d1cf277ad4a617
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add a playbook to set local facts on newton redeploy

The newton redeployment process, while fairly straight forward, cna have
issues due to transient problems or DB states. This change sets all of
the known local facts for a newton deployment within the new target
containers during the redeployment process. This will ensure that all
local facts are set prior to running the redeployment which will also
effectively finish the upgrade for the cloud.

Change-Id: I8f04bbda500459222e727c3de9d1cf277ad4a617
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: [DNM] Test inventory with static YAML based inventory
messages:
[{'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-11 04:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-11 07:10:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Please don't add code that's not necessary.

ansible provides a way to convert inventories already, and we should make use of it. See https://evrard.me/convert-ansible-inventories-with-ansible-inventory-cli .

Next to that, there are a few patches necessary to make the static inventories work, which are all worked on the topic no_dynamic_inventory. When this will be ready, I will indeed add a gate test using only static inventories.

For readability a YAML based inventory might be used. But I have no strong opinion on YAML vs ini."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-11 15:30:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Please don't add code that's not necessary.

Please explain, nothing here is in conflict with the ansible-inventory tool.

 > 
 > ansible provides a way to convert inventories already, and we
 > should make use of it. See https://evrard.me/convert-ansible-inventories-with-ansible-inventory-cli
 > .

I had a look here however I don't see a way to convert from a JSON inventory on disk to a YAML or INI inventory and maintain the actual structure of the inventory.

Using the ansible-inventory tool with a script and the following command `/opt/ansible-runtime/bin/ansible-inventory -i test.sh -y --list --vars > inventory.yml`: 
http://paste.openstack.org/show/725569

Things are considerably worse using the actual dynamic inventory script `/opt/ansible-runtime/bin/ansible-inventory -i /opt/openstack-ansible/inventory/dynamic_inventory.py --yaml --list --vars > inventory.yml`: 
http://paste.openstack.org/show/725571

Using the script found in this review the JSON inventory is directly converted into YAML which is fairly easy to understand and considerably smaller than the two other methods:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/725570

 > 
 > Next to that, there are a few patches necessary to make the static
 > inventories work, which are all worked on the topic
 > no_dynamic_inventory. When this will be ready, I will indeed add a
 > gate test using only static inventories.

This is in fact already working. However I am reviewing the reviews with the "no_dynamic_inventory" tag now. The purpose of this review is to not conflict with the work you're doing, more so just figuring out how to use a static inventory with OSA which is coming from an actual business need we have now.

 > 
 > For readability a YAML based inventory might be used. But I have no
 > strong opinion on YAML vs ini.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-11 15:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-11 19:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-05-07 03:27:07.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
[DNM] Test inventory with static YAML based inventory

This change implements a simple Ansible JSON to YAML converter which
will allow a user to convert an existing dynamic JSON inventory to a
static YAML based inventory. This was done in an effort to test what's
possible and what works and to see if there's continued interest in
going the static inventory route.

Change-Id: Ibc971d152f8fd985c0eac82edfd3d0d29479f3d7
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
bootstrap: install network-scripts if EL8

network-scripts is required by the network service which is enabled
in tasks/main.yml.
Also run this block of tasks on EL8 only, where it's actually needed.

Change-Id: I2e43de001938bcdec96875ede0ef52d4742dc01c
Closes-bug: 1827277

commit_message:
Introduce tripleo-container-rm

tripleo-container-rm is the new role that replaces tripleo-docker-rm which
is in charge of tearing down containers running in Docker or Podman.
If the container_cli is Podman, the role takes care of systemd cleanup for
both the container and its healthcheck if it does exist.

Change-Id: I3fc5b351c3e20ab01953a510bd71a70d3c083527

commit_message:
Allow to change registry port in container-build

Add a role variable: push_registry_port which default
to 8787 and this variable  can be used to set different
port to be used by container registry set by build-containers
role.

This is required in cases where 8787 port is used by
some other service.

Change-Id: Ia0dd8ce3a62a72d056c57e434b93237663b54c22

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-02 15:55:54.000000000', 'message': "Fix chown command in write_inputs_file function

The tripleo-common sudoers file allows an owner change on the
validations identity file. The command is only allowed with the `-h`
option, but this option isn't used in the `write_inputs_file` python
code. This breaks validation runs started through Mistral.

This patch adds this option to the `chown` command. It also removes an
useless line in the sudoers file.

Change-Id: Idd3098cfa3aab5dd618645e54b922f90cd9ae13f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d0831dc4ce70ddc8ac733c8946afaa014ff7a2ef)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix chown command in write_inputs_file function

The tripleo-common sudoers file allows an owner change on the
validations identity file. The command is only allowed with the `-h`
option, but this option isn't used in the `write_inputs_file` python
code. This breaks validation runs started through Mistral.

This patch adds this option to the `chown` command. It also removes an
useless line in the sudoers file.

Change-Id: Idd3098cfa3aab5dd618645e54b922f90cd9ae13f
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d0831dc4ce70ddc8ac733c8946afaa014ff7a2ef)

commit_message:
Add Wazuh support to the Elastic-Stack

Wazuh provides us the ability to begin capturing and monitoring OSSEC.
The changes implement the agent, api, and management framework for wazuh
within a single environment. Clustered wazuh will be added later.

Documentation for Wazuh can be found here: https://documentation.wazuh.com

Change-Id: Ib6bd330706cf818f5f7cb1b8c4666d3541b7bbcd
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-03 05:01:19.000000000', 'message': "Backport nova placement api healthcheck from pike

The nova placement API needs to check for 401 given that it does not
have a proper healthcheck API. Without this change haproxy will gladly
try and use any node within the cluster, even if it's returning in
error.

Change-Id: I1efe2f29e25f144388163a59c7b626baf3f91afd
Closes-Bug: #1721356
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Backport nova placement api healthcheck from pike

The nova placement API needs to check for 401 given that it does not
have a proper healthcheck API. Without this change haproxy will gladly
try and use any node within the cluster, even if it's returning in
error.

Change-Id: I1efe2f29e25f144388163a59c7b626baf3f91afd
Closes-Bug: #1721356
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Add new attributes to instance

This change adds launched_at/started_at/deleted_at attribute to instance.

Rely on started_at/ended_at of Gnocchi to known when the operation have
done is not precise. Nova records the exact time of this event, just
copy them to Gnocchi.

Backport to queens.
Signed-off-by: Ryan McCabe <rmccabe@redhat.com>

Change-Id: If7870fd525d1ef58e4c2dbbbf93525bab3623b0f
(cherry picked from commit 36414e1cebe3a43d962f8d2adfe7cc34742e9057)

[{'created': '2018-05-14 17:02:44.000000000', 'message': 'Use fan out when deploying with nspawn

When deploying with nspawn containers the deployment process can be made
simpler and faster by using a fan out. This change will group the
containers by "primary" and "all". The deployment process will create
the primary containers on all physical hosts which runs through the long
deployment process. Once these primary containers are online the rest of

commit_message:
Use fan out when deploying with nspawn

When deploying with nspawn containers the deployment process can be made
simpler and faster by using a fan out. This change will group the
containers by "primary" and "all". The deployment process will create
the primary containers on all physical hosts which runs through the long
deployment process. Once these primary containers are online the rest of
the containers are then built off the primary image using a clone.

Change-Id: I4e5a1c784e38fb918308c857d20aad6e70bf484a
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Change include to include_tasks

The old include option is being deprecated this coverts the role to use
the new option.

Change-Id: Ia603411862538c6461c2626c20762b796d8f3ae4
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Tune-up the rabbitmq role for efficiency

The rabbitmq role has grown organically over the last few cycles. This
change cleans up the role and applies some of our more established
patterns. This will allow the role to be more efficient.

For service consistency and isolation a configuration file for private
devices and service slices have been added into the role. These options
provide for a consistent and isolated deployment no matter if it's in a
container or on baremetal.

Change-Id: Iaf61081d14ef9fa43c72c08a65f6793261c4ef35
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Simplify the creation of test networks

This change modifies the test networks creation to be a simple service
file instead of unique system interface files.

Change-Id: I0a83399ccf8d7a889e7dbebec4a5323c48ede537
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: Convert systemd services to common role(s)
messages: [{'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-03-19 04:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-03-19 04:23:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-05-07 02:41:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nfixed in a different way'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-19 04:08:06.000000000', 'message': 'Convert systemd services to common role(s)

This removes the systemd service templates and tasks from this role and
leverages a common systemd service role instead. This change removes a
lot of code duplication across all roles all without sacrificing features
or functionality. The intention of this change is to ensure uniformity and

commit_message:
Convert systemd services to common role(s)

This removes the systemd service templates and tasks from this role and
leverages a common systemd service role instead. This change removes a
lot of code duplication across all roles all without sacrificing features
or functionality. The intention of this change is to ensure uniformity and
reduce the maintenance burden on the community when sweeping changes are
needed. The exterior role is built to be OSA compatible and may be pulled
into tree should we deem it necessary.

Change-Id: I5ab3f31be486b5a4a6311086cc39f5ff1c6ed964
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: Modify LXC container create to JIT create

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-04 16:44:46.000000000', 'message': 'Modify LXC container create to JIT create

The container builds with are now following a JIT pattern. This gives us
greater flexability and capabilities in terms of how we deploy the
containers and how we build our environments. Each resouce requiring a
container will run the "$TYPE-containers-create.yml" playbook and only
build the resources needed at runtime. This also ensures that
configuration changes specific to a resouce are always applied to the
container and that any new containers needed throught the lifetime of a
deployment are automatically created.

Change-Id: Iaeab87b3451af8ceb60c4f8d6d32cfa9fb3f3d2c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-08-04 17:10:41.000000000', 'message': 'Modify LXC container create to JIT create

commit_message:
Modify LXC container create to JIT create

The container builds with are now following a JIT pattern. This gives us
greater flexability and capabilities in terms of how we deploy the
containers and how we build our environments. Each resouce requiring a
container will run the "$TYPE-containers-create.yml" playbook and only
build the resources needed at runtime. This also ensures that
configuration changes specific to a resouce are always applied to the
container and that any new containers needed throught the lifetime of a
deployment are automatically created.

Depends-On: I6ef6e280e9697c45e428ec9dc519cfd0f82b651a
Change-Id: Iaeab87b3451af8ceb60c4f8d6d32cfa9fb3f3d2c
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Finally managed to get somewhere..... you appear to also need osprofiler and elasticsearch pip packages installed on the host to make this work.

Plus /openstack/venvs/horizon-17.0.4/lib/python2.7/site-packages/openstack_dashboard/contrib/developer/dashboard.py has a check for DEBUG being enabled before enabling the developer dashboards.

If DEBUG is left as False and the developer dashboards are enabled, then they fail to load, resulting in the horizon we app starting but *all* of the panels being absent due to an exception.

So it looks like it is mandatory to put DEBUG=True in local_settings.py if the developer ui is enabled.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-08 13:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The default documentation covers this in detail which can be found here: https://docs.openstack.org/osprofiler/queens/user/integration.html'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-12 04:07:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

In the case of horizon, the elasticsearch library is similar to the various dashboard libraries that are also installed by default but may not be enabled by default. At this point the only supported dashboard backend for osprofiler and the developer dashbaords is elasticsearch. Wont' accept this as long as its not opt-in."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-06-26 16:56:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

For me, we need this to be opt-in because:
- This has an impact on repo build, which will cause issues for some other roles that aren't tested in the integrated by default (like searchlight)
- This has an impact on deployers that don't want or aren't allowed to package elasticsearch. This could become a friction to deploy OSA instead of a positive improvement.

Last, but not least, until this has a new scenario to test its behavior, I'd be enclined to refuse it."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-06-26 17:28:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> For me, we need this to be opt-in because:
 > - This has an impact on repo build, which will cause issues for
 > some other roles that aren't tested in the integrated by default
 > (like searchlight)
 > - This has an impact on deployers that don't want or aren't allowed
 > to package elasticsearch. This could become a friction to deploy
 > OSA instead of a positive improvement.
 > 
 > Last, but not least, until this has a new scenario to test its
 > behavior, I'd be enclined to refuse it.

Make this opt-in, and I will remove my vote."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-26 18:00:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> For me, we need this to be opt-in because:
 > - This has an impact on repo build, which will cause issues for
 > some other roles that aren't tested in the integrated by default
 > (like searchlight)

How is this in conflict with searchlight or even relevant to the inclusion of this package for the purpose of enabling an optional debug feature "osprofiler".

 > - This has an impact on deployers that don't want or aren't allowed
 > to package elasticsearch. 

The pip install capabilities are from a source based build. If the deployer is using a package based build the venvs will not exist rendering this argument irrelevant. Additionally I'd like to know what we're catering to when it comes to "deployers that don't want or aren't allowed to package elasticsearch"? This requirement is in global requirements so there's no licencing issues from the perspective of OpenStack.

 > This could become a friction to deploy OSA instead of a positive improvement.

You're going to need to fill me in on how any of this is possible or has any impact on deployers? As a large scale deployer I can say with 100% certainty this has no impact on the running environment and does not result in ANY conflicts (I have all of this in production today).

 > 
 > Last, but not least, until this has a new scenario to test its
 > behavior, I'd be enclined to refuse it.

The test run within this change included this package. No new scenario is needed to test the inclusion of a library that is unused. However we could add a test that wires Horizon up to elasticsearch, which would require installing elasticsearch in the test scenario. If that would make you more open to this change I'd be happy to do this.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-26 18:05:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> > For me, we need this to be opt-in because:
 > > - This has an impact on repo build, which will cause issues for
 > > some other roles that aren't tested in the integrated by default
 > > (like searchlight)
 > > - This has an impact on deployers that don't want or aren't
 > allowed
 > > to package elasticsearch. This could become a friction to deploy
 > > OSA instead of a positive improvement.
 > >
 > > Last, but not least, until this has a new scenario to test its
 > > behavior, I'd be enclined to refuse it.
 > 
 > Make this opt-in, and I will remove my vote.

The library will only be used if osprofiler is enabled, thus it is already opt-in. That said, the documented osprofiler connection string being used in horizon requires the library be present else django will stacktrace, horizon does not gracefully handle a non-existent library. By simply including the library we don't have this issue and can be sure that enabling a debug along with profiling (operating tooling used to better understand how an environment is working) will not impact the horizon runtime."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-06-27 07:30:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> > For me, we need this to be opt-in because:
 > > - This has an impact on repo build, which will cause issues for
 > > some other roles that aren't tested in the integrated by default
 > > (like searchlight)
 > 
 > How is this in conflict with searchlight or even relevant to the
 > inclusion of this package for the purpose of enabling an optional
 > debug feature "osprofiler".

Because searchlight is requiring elasticsearch, freezer, and osprofiler is expecting 2.x, that's the reason of the u-c of elasticsearch is 2.x.

So tell me if I am wrong:
1) Deployers that don't profile have elastic installed anyway (which is opposite to the idea we've discussed earlier this cycle to "clean up things").
2) Elasticsearch python library should match the ES installed (see https://pypi.org/project/elasticsearch/ compatibility section)
3) Deployers that want to use osprofiler with ES 2.x can have this automatically wired by defining another variable to trigger that behavior. If they already have to override things, why do we need to force things for deployer case 1) above, as the python elasticsearch package addition could as well be an user level override (if the code is written differently).
4) Deployers that want to use osprofiler with a more recent version of ES are not covered here, as they would need to pin things to an untested version of elasticsearch for osprofiler
(http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/osprofiler/tree/test-requirements.txt)
5) 

My concern is that we introducing code that's more risky than anything:
- Wrong expectations set for deployers using ES by default (who will deployer 2.x nowadays?)
- Code is carried while this could be limited to a doc change and a minimal code change (the templates, for convenience for example).
- The user experience is pretty bad: If I have no docs for this feature, I'd try to enable it, fail on it three times each time with a new error message. "Oh you need to enable this now"
- Nothing is tested nor documented. The whole osprofiler addition was done without even a spec. That's against what we've done to do things in the open.
- This is adding more cruft to an horizon role which definitely needs overhaul to make sure third party extensions are easier to reach. (new custom panel anyone?)
- Making sure this works with ES 5.x or 6.x, by adding a test scenario for it.

I agree this seems a lot of work to get this feature in.

But please notice this is our practices: https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible/latest/contributor/contribute.html#working-on-new-features

So respecting the practices is the minimum I am expecting before going further.

 > 
 > > - This has an impact on deployers that don't want or aren't
 > allowed
 > > to package elasticsearch.
 > 
 > The pip install capabilities are from a source based build. If the
 > deployer is using a package based build the venvs will not exist
 > rendering this argument irrelevant. Additionally I'd like to know
 > what we're catering to when it comes to "deployers that don't want
 > or aren't allowed to package elasticsearch"? This requirement is in
 > global requirements so there's no licencing issues from the
 > perspective of OpenStack.

I didn't mean distro packaging, but instead "venv packaging".
If you are using artifacts, how can you tell now to use the venv with ES 5.x, ES 6.x, or ES 2.x, depending on the deployer?
This looks like burden to me.

 > > This could become a friction to deploy OSA instead of a positive
 > improvement.

 > 
 > You're going to need to fill me in on how any of this is possible
 > or has any impact on deployers? As a large scale deployer I can say
 > with 100% certainty this has no impact on the running environment
 > and does not result in ANY conflicts (I have all of this in
 > production today).

Are you artefacting this? (Whether distro packages, or venv build packages)?
When I was still at rackspace, that was a requirement, and I regularily see and hear
people talking about have better artefacts.

Distro packages are one way to solve it, but venvs is also a way to solve it for deployers which aren't packagers.

On top of that, if you're packaging with distro packages, you now have the funny issue of which python-elasticsearch to install, because you can now have conflicts. I admit, this could be solved by packaging python-elasticsearch2 python-elasticsearch5 and python-elasticsearch6.
But then the user friendliness still applies... So I guess what we need instead is a better mechanism.

And that's where I think a spec should have gone in before that patch.

 > 
 > >
 > > Last, but not least, until this has a new scenario to test its
 > > behavior, I'd be enclined to refuse it.
 > 
 > The test run within this change included this package. No new
 > scenario is needed to test the inclusion of a library that is
 > unused. However we could add a test that wires Horizon up to
 > elasticsearch, which would require installing elasticsearch in the
 > test scenario. If that would make you more open to this change I'd
 > be happy to do this.

I don't see where the horizon_enable_developer_ui is set to true in any test.
For me that should be enough to warrant a test.

Also: if you consider that this is a bug for horizon to stacktrace when the library is not present, while not filing a bug?

I am pretty sure this whole elasticsearch/osprofiler story could have been discussed far before the first actual code, and that would have been easier to merge.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-27 15:36:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> > > For me, we need this to be opt-in because:
> > > - This has an impact on repo build, which will cause issues for
> > > some other roles that aren't tested in the integrated by
> default
> > > (like searchlight)
> >
> > How is this in conflict with searchlight or even relevant to the
> > inclusion of this package for the purpose of enabling an optional
> > debug feature "osprofiler".
> 
> Because searchlight is requiring elasticsearch, freezer, and
> osprofiler is expecting 2.x, that's the reason of the u-c of
> elasticsearch is 2.x.
> 
> So tell me if I am wrong:

Yes you are mostly wrong. 

> 1) Deployers that don't profile have elastic installed anyway
> (which is opposite to the idea we've discussed earlier this cycle
> to "clean up things").

Correct we're installing a lib, that might be used, similar to many of the libs
we ship today along with our openstack services (See: nova, cinder, neutron, 
magnum, heat).

> 2) Elasticsearch python library should match the ES installed (see
> https://pypi.org/project/elasticsearch/ compatibility section)

Correct, however including the lib will allow a user to set the version using an
override as they see fit. The inclusion of the lib which is in global 
requirements.

> 3) Deployers that want to use osprofiler with ES 2.x can have this
> automatically wired by defining another variable to trigger that
> behavior. If they already have to override things, why do we need
> to force things for deployer case 1) above, as the python
> elasticsearch package addition could as well be an user level
> override (if the code is written differently).

See above. It can already be overridden as it is today.

> 4) Deployers that want to use osprofiler with a more recent version
> of ES are not covered here, as they would need to pin things to an
> untested version of elasticsearch for osprofiler
> (http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/osprofiler/tree/test-requirements.txt)

Correct, deployers can use any version of ELK under the sun and the libs need to
match what they're deploying. This is known and documented in the OPS repo for 
our Elasticsearch deployment solution.

> 5)
>
> My concern is that we introducing code that's more risky than
> anything:
> - Wrong expectations set for deployers using ES by default (who
> will deployer 2.x nowadays?)

The expectations are not wrong. The package needs to be included, if a deployer
Its a well known fact that the package needs to match the version of 
elasticsearch being deployed. As mentioned several times before, this is 
documented in the OPS repo.

> - Code is carried while this could be limited to a doc change and a
> minimal code change (the templates, for convenience for example).

This is a minimal code change. We're not adding a mess of code to enable 
osprofiler, just a package.

> - The user experience is pretty bad: If I have no docs for this
> feature, I'd try to enable it, fail on it three times each time
> with a new error message. "Oh you need to enable this now"

The docs for enabling osprofiler are presently in the OPS repo.

> - Nothing is tested nor documented. The whole osprofiler addition
> was done without even a spec. That's against what we've done to do
> things in the open.

Wrong, and pedantic. The osprofiler addition was a python package add we didn't 
do much else at this point. If we're being really picky we should have opened a
bug given that osprofiler is currently in the paste pipelines and is functionaly
broken without the inclusion of this package.

> - This is adding more cruft to an horizon role which definitely
> needs overhaul to make sure third party extensions are easier to
> reach. (new custom panel anyone?)

We're not adding cruft nor is this point of any concern to the enablement of the
panels that horizon comes with.

> - Making sure this works with ES 5.x or 6.x, by adding a test
> scenario for it.

We can add tests for elasticsearch 6 if that would make you feel better about 
this.

> I agree this seems a lot of work to get this feature in.
> 
> But please notice this is our practices: https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible/latest/contributor/contribute.html#working-on-new-features
> 
> So respecting the practices is the minimum I am expecting before
> going further.

This is a non-sense argument given that there's so much going on, even in you
own commit history that is working against what is specifically in that
document. Additionally we're not adding new openstack features, we're enhancing
and otherwise fixing features we've already had, which is based specifically
on operator use-cases.

> 
> >
> > > - This has an impact on deployers that don't want or aren't
> > allowed
> > > to package elasticsearch.
> >
> > The pip install capabilities are from a source based build. If
> the
> > deployer is using a package based build the venvs will not exist
> > rendering this argument irrelevant. Additionally I'd like to know
> > what we're catering to when it comes to "deployers that don't
> want
> > or aren't allowed to package elasticsearch"? This requirement is
> in
> > global requirements so there's no licencing issues from the
> > perspective of OpenStack.
> 
> I didn't mean distro packaging, but instead "venv packaging".
> If you are using artifacts, how can you tell now to use the venv
> with ES 5.x, ES 6.x, or ES 2.x, depending on the deployer?
> This looks like burden to me.
> 

We're simply providing the package here, like others, if no version override is
provided the default from global requirements is used. This is how OSA has 
worked for years. That said when this feature is enabled we have recommendations
to define the package version which can be found within our OPS repository for
the deployment of Elasticsearch [ https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-ops/tree/master/elk_metrics_6x#optional--add-osprofiler-to-an-openstack-ansible-deployment ].

> > > This could become a friction to deploy OSA instead of a
> positive
> > improvement.
> 
> >
> > You're going to need to fill me in on how any of this is possible
> > or has any impact on deployers? As a large scale deployer I can
> say
> > with 100% certainty this has no impact on the running environment
> > and does not result in ANY conflicts (I have all of this in
> > production today).
> 
> Are you artefacting this? (Whether distro packages, or venv build
> packages)?
> When I was still at rackspace, that was a requirement, and I
> regularily see and hear
> people talking about have better artefacts.

I have this enabled using the documentation found in the OPS repo which is
running in production today: [ https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-ops/tree/master/elk_metrics_6x ].
This is not using any "artifacts" to speak of.

> Distro packages are one way to solve it, but venvs is also a way to
> solve it for deployers which aren't packagers.
> 
> On top of that, if you're packaging with distro packages, you now
> have the funny issue of which python-elasticsearch to install,
> because you can now have conflicts. I admit, this could be solved
> by packaging python-elasticsearch2 python-elasticsearch5 and
> python-elasticsearch6.
> But then the user friendliness still applies... So I guess what we
> need instead is a better mechanism.

The distro package deployment solution is not a primary use-case at this moment.
Given that we're still primarily a source based deployment solution the 
inclusion of this package is in-line with how we do everything else. Distro 
packaging will need to conform to source based builds in OSA not the other-way 
around.

> And that's where I think a spec should have gone in before that
> patch.
> 
> >
> > >
> > > Last, but not least, until this has a new scenario to test its
> > > behavior, I'd be enclined to refuse it.
> >
> > The test run within this change included this package. No new
> > scenario is needed to test the inclusion of a library that is
> > unused. However we could add a test that wires Horizon up to
> > elasticsearch, which would require installing elasticsearch in
> the
> > test scenario. If that would make you more open to this change
> I'd
> > be happy to do this.
> 
> I don't see where the horizon_enable_developer_ui is set to true in
> any test.
> For me that should be enough to warrant a test.

It's not enabled, however the lib, which does nothing on it's own, is being
built in the venv.

> Also: if you consider that this is a bug for horizon to stacktrace
> when the library is not present, while not filing a bug?

The stacktrace is not a bug in horizon, its an issue in django and is caused
because the config is in fact python code.

> I am pretty sure this whole elasticsearch/osprofiler story could
> have been discussed far before the first actual code, and that
> would have been easier to merge.

You're simply being obstinate. In fact there is an elasticsearch spec that was 
created and merged [ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/527769/ ]. As noted in our
previous conversations the use of osprofiler is already deployed in all of our 
openstack pipelines which means that we've had, for a long time, a pipeline 
capability that has effectively been broken.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2019-05-07 02:30:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

no longer viable.'}]

commit_message:
Add developer panels to horizon

The developer panels can be enabled to provide users additional workflow
options and insight into their clouds. This change adds options to
enable the developer panels and connect osprofiler to an elasticsearch
backend.

Change-Id: Ie0f983193d181b8e5a6aff94cfdbbf4cf6200848
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

[{'created': '2018-10-08 20:00:56.000000000', 'message': 'Further simplify the networking stack by eliminating veths

The networking stack, in legacy mode, was building out links and veth
pairs to any networking device which has a "bridge" type. This change
eliminates all of that. With the introduction with `host_only` config,
and host scopped addresses / routes the use of veth pairs is no longer
required. The macvlan interface is now spawned off of any interface
passed into config and no longer needs to use a special code path for
"bridge" devices.

Change-Id: I6455278efecaa7d8ad34886c3b0fc1f37f19873b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Further simplify the networking stack by eliminating veths

The networking stack, in legacy mode, was building out links and veth
pairs to any networking device which has a "bridge" type. This change
eliminates all of that. With the introduction with `host_only` config,
and host scopped addresses / routes the use of veth pairs is no longer
required. The macvlan interface is now spawned off of any interface
passed into config and no longer needs to use a special code path for
"bridge" devices.

Depends-On: Id20afab8b705f6528ba5575ee4704c1661e6e65c
Change-Id: I6455278efecaa7d8ad34886c3b0fc1f37f19873b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

I'd rather think of other approaches before heading that way. It's barely ansible compliant, and I think the value it brings is low. We could instead just remove the setup-* wrappers in the gates and run the playbooks with & in a shell script (Ok I am exagerating a little).

I'd rather focus on many other improvements, like the reduction of nodes/groups/inventory, which would tremendously help."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-08-26 00:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> I'd rather think of other approaches before heading that way. It's
 > barely ansible compliant, and I think the value it brings is low.
 > We could instead just remove the setup-* wrappers in the gates and
 > run the playbooks with & in a shell script (Ok I am exagerating a
 > little).
 > 
 > I'd rather focus on many other improvements, like the reduction of
 > nodes/groups/inventory, which would tremendously help.

I disagree. With the instances of success, we're already seeing a 30+ minute improvement. This is doing nothing but executing the playbooks which have no dependency on one another in parallel and at this time only effects the gate. If we accept async tasks, I can't see how introducing async playbooks is of any violation to Ansible itself."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-08-26 00:50:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I really do not believe that the added complexity is worth it. This is adding a bunch of stuff making it even harder to comprehend what's going on."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-08-29 14:24:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> I really do not believe that the added complexity is worth it. This
 > is adding a bunch of stuff making it even harder to comprehend
 > what's going on.

I agree that its adding some code, but it's no more complex. The output is printed in the order the plays are executed and should we encounter an error, the thread will halt the rest of the runs and print the log output which is exactly what we have today. This change in a 30+ minute improvement focused only on testing and the gate. Maybe we can iterate on it to make it better but this definitely seems worth it."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-08-29 14:30:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

I'm 100% in agreement with reordering the playbooks as you've done here. The ordering of those has driven me nuts.

The patch does work, but I'm curious about that runner script where there's bash and python included. It's a tough one to read and it might be challenging to fix bugs later.  Would it make sense to separate the bash and python into separate files?  Or could the runner script be completely in python?"}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2017-08-29 14:52:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-08-29 14:54:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> I'm 100% in agreement with reordering the playbooks as you've done
 > here. The ordering of those has driven me nuts.
 > 
 > The patch does work, but I'm curious about that runner script where
 > there's bash and python included. It's a tough one to read and it
 > might be challenging to fix bugs later.  Would it make sense to
 > separate the bash and python into separate files?  Or could the
 > runner script be completely in python?

It's technically possible to have a full python runner.
I think that if the order is painful, worst case, we can rename the playbooks. No need for variables and weird things."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-08-29 15:21:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> > I'm 100% in agreement with reordering the playbooks as you've
 > done
 > > here. The ordering of those has driven me nuts.
 > >
 > > The patch does work, but I'm curious about that runner script
 > where
 > > there's bash and python included. It's a tough one to read and it
 > > might be challenging to fix bugs later.  Would it make sense to
 > > separate the bash and python into separate files?  Or could the
 > > runner script be completely in python?

 > It's technically possible to have a full python runner.
